Description: Twelve beads and or amulets of various shapes and materials, now strung together. From left: roundish bead in yellow glass a (0.9 x 0.75 cm); tubular glazed composition (?) bead b (0.8 x 1.7 cm) brown colour with spiral white glaze inlay; rounded bead c in pinkish stone (0.85 x 0.85 cm), with irregular, rough surface; round bead d in yellow glaze composition (0.9 x 0.7 cm), very eroded; rounded bead e in turquoise glaze composition (1.05 x 0.85 cm), slightly eroded; relatively rounded bead f in turquoise glaze composition (1.15 x 1 cm); quite irregularly-shaped bead g in black and white hard stone (porphyre?) (0.95 x 0.75 cm); glazed composition bead h (0.7 x 0.65 cm), with pale yellow core and burnt glaze; yellow glazed composition bead i, in the shape of an openwork one-sided wedjat-eye within an oval serrated frame (1.6 x 1.4 x 0.3 cm), eroded; glazed composition bead j, of rectangular flat shape and decorated with a cross (“X”) on both side (1.8 x 1.6 x 0.4 cm) with faint remains of turquoise glaze; irregularly-shaped and broken bead k in blue and white glass (?) (0.75 x 0.75 cm); rounded turquoise glazed composition bead l (0.55 x 0.55 cm).
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Great Temenos, just north of the enclosure wall (?)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The beads pertaining to this reconstructed necklace could have been found in various contexts in Naukratis: the glass beads are later in date than the wedjat-eye within an oval serrated frame (Late Period, especially 26th dynasty). However, a trench done "just N. of the ‘Great Wall’" of the Great Temenos provided many beads along numerous amulets (Hogarth diary – 2nd of May 1903; on this context: Masson forthcoming). These beads might come from such a context. For various examples of open-work wedjat-eyes from Naukratis (list not exhaustive): London, Petrie Museum UC54636, Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,84.i, Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.694, Bristol and City Art Gallery & Museum H3436. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds.), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 22nd-23rd June 2013.

4 glazed composition plain spherical (Xia type PN8, Late Period), 1 glazed composition mellon (PD21, Late Period), 1 glazed composition rectangular with crosses (PD 16/65, Late Period), 1 unidentified stone (Late Period?), 1 glass stratified eye-bead (GD26? Late Period), 1 glass spiral (GD66, Late Period/Ptolemaic?), 1 green glass (Roman?), 1 gold glass (Roman?). Xia, N. 2014, Ancient Egyptian Beads, Heidelberg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.413) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather poor, all beads quite worn
